body.p:
Foster Bracken County Ky May 15th 1863
To The Honorable Governor of the State of Ky Sir

We the undersigned members of the Board of Trustees of the Town of Foster herewith send you the Poll Books and certificates of an election ordered and held by us on Friday May 8th 1863 for the purpose of electing a police Judge to fill the vacancy occasioned by the absence of Jesse Gray former incumbent Mr. Gray not having made a formal resignation it is but due to your Honor to explain to you the cause of the vacancy which is as follows. Mr Gray left this place some two months ago for an indiffinite Period for the Purpose as he stated of taking service in the Gun boats either as Pilot or Captain, which service he writes, he immediately obtained upon reaching Cairo believing that he could not act as Judge and at the same time be on the Mississippi in the Gun boat service, and feeling our need of a Judge we formaly declared the office vacant and called the Election which result we herewith enclose duly certified all of which we respectfully submit hoping you will commission the Judge elect at your Earliest convenience

G. S. Kimberly
Clk of the Board
Robert Neal
A. W. Schoolfield
Jos. H H Reed
O C Pollock M. D. } Trustees
The Police Judge of Foster holds his office for the Term of 4 years (1 Acts 1859-60 p. 350)
Nothing stated within shows that a vacancy existed at the time of the election to supply the place of the former incombent
The Trustees have not the power of removal from office of the Police Judge -- This must be done by indictment or impeachment.
The papers do not, in my opinion, show that Mr Markley is entitled to be commissioned as Police Judge of Foster.

Foster
Wanting appt of Police Judge refused see opinion of Atty Genl.
Ansd June 2. 1863
